Summary My expertise is in utilizing deep learning to accelerate generic applications. This is a new area that holds incredible potential to improve performance (with minimal design costs) on a wide range of applications, from image/video processing to graphics and scientific computing. Experience Graduate Research Assistant Stanford University June 2012  – Present (3 years 3 months) Stanford University EMEURO: An approximate computing framework for universal acceleration 
-- Design complexity for high performance applications is increasing rapidly 
-- Many algorithms (e.g., signal/image processing, graphics, simulations) can tolerate small computational errors due to relaxed constraints 
-- Minimal reductions in accuracy can often be traded for orders of magnitude in performance improvement 
-- EMEURO is a deep learning based framework for emulating and accelerating applications, achieving up to 109X speedup with less than 3% error 
-- Upcoming submission & Thesis Graduate Research Assistant Stanford University January 2011  –  June 2012  (1 year 6 months) Building a completely unsupervised object-recognition deep learning algorithm 
-- Most learning algorithms utilize labeled data to learn structure of the world 
-- In contrast, humans learn on vast amounts of unlabeled data 
-- Worked to develop a completely unsupervised deep learning system that scales to many object categories 
-- Results showed significant promise on 'Faces in the Wild' dataset 
-- Developed sparse neural net compiler to accelerate training 
-- Publication: "Utilizing static analysis and code generation to accelerate neural networks," ICML 2012 Graduate Research Assistant Stanford University October 2008  –  March 2010  (1 year 6 months) Optimized FPGA architecture for scalable Deep Belief Net (DBN) acceleration 
-- DBNs are a very promising new neural net learning algorithm for general high-dimension data mining and pattern recognition 
-- DBNs are high memory bandwidth, matrix multiplication-based algorithms 
-- Developed modular DBN acceleration architecture on Altera Stratix-III board 
-- Scalable to multi-board for higher dimension input data 
-- Publication: "A highly scalable restricted Boltzmann machine FPGA implementation," FPL 2009 Graduate Research Assistant Stanford University June 2012  – Present (3 years 3 months) Stanford University EMEURO: An approximate computing framework for universal acceleration

Primarily focusing on developing a deeper understanding of Neurological Diseases and psychiatric illness such as Schizophrenia, Bipolar Disorder, Autism Spectrum Disorders, and Alzheimer's Disease. 
 
Skills associated with position: 
•	Husbandry/Animal skills in mice: scruffing, handling, breeding, weaning and separating litters, cervical dislocation, anesthesia, ear tagging, and intraperitoneal injections. 
•	Tissue collection in mice: liver, kidney, lung and heart collection, and perfusion.  
•	Adult murine CNS regional dissection, adult murine CNS sub-regional enrichment, embryonic forebrain and striatum dissection, microtome/vibratome dissection, and cyrostat brain sectioning. 
•	Biomarker analysis: Western Blotting, RNA extraction, tissue homogenization, RT-PCR, Immunohistochemistry sectioning, staining, and imaging.  
•	Tissue culturing: Primary neuronal cultures. Summary Michal is a second-year MD candidate at Harvard Medical School. In summer 2014, she conducted orthopedic surgery research of the hand at Johns Hopkins exploring quality of life metrics in patients with trapeziometacarpal osteoarthritis. At Harvard Medical School, Michal served as a Co-President of the LGBTQ and Allied Students at Harvard Medical School/Harvard School of Dental Medicine (LAHMS) and the Harvard Medical School Med Students for Choice (MSFC) chapter. In addition, she researches barriers to care for trans* patients at Fenway Health and co-chairs the Medical Education team at Harvard's Crimson Care Collaborative. She is a student member on the Massachusetts Medical Society's Committee on LGBT Matters. She is also actively involved in Harvard Medical School's curricular reform efforts through her work with the Health Equity in the Curriculum working group. 
 
Prior to Harvard Medical School, Michal served as an Allan Rosenfield Fellow at the Foundation for AIDS Research (amfAR). Before that, she tracked Affordable Care Act implementation as a Research Assistant working on a grant from the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation. 
 
Through these experiences, Michal has developed a passion for the clinical research and advocacy work. Summary Michal is a second-year MD candidate at Harvard Medical School. Summary I am excited about sending things into space. During the course of my undergraduate and graduate studies, I have worked on the design of six different space missions and have thoroughly enjoyed each of those experiences. I love designing and building things, be it antennas, circuit boards or mechanical assemblies. My goal is to work on novel space mission architectures and technologies that enable future space missions for understanding climate and Earth science, for space-based astronomy and space physics applications and for expanding the human frontier outwards in the solar system. Experience Research Assistant Stanford University June 2014  – Present (1 year 3 months) Space Environment and Satellite Systems Lab •	Studying hypervelocity particle impacts in space and their possible link with electrical anomalies on satellites

•	Led the design of a CubeSat mission for in-situ measurement of plasma and electromagnetic emission from hypervelocity impacts in space 
•	Project leader for hypervelocity impact experiments carried out at the impact test facility in Boulder, Colorado 
•	Leading the design of a CubeSat for studying the radiation and dust environment around Europa Summer Fellow Center for Space Nuclear Research June 2014  –  August 2014  (3 months) Idaho Falls, Idaho •	Led a student team for the design of a radioisotope thermophotovoltaic power system to demonstrate its spaceworthiness.
